Would dinosaur again.Helpful?Yes|NoReplyShareMoreJul 21 2015brad cFeaturedIve loved all of the Jurassic Park movies in the series ever since I first saw them. I love the realistic looking dinosaurs and all of the intense action. After taking over a decade long break Universal Pictures came out with this new installment in the series. I was hooked the moment I saw the first trailer tease. After watching this movie I was not disappointed in the slightest. Chris Pratt does a wonderful job of interacting with the "dinosaurs" and made it such a thrill. What I thought made this movie so much better and different from the previous films is that there are a lot more human casualties.; the entire theme park gets attacked by dinosaurs which contrasts the previous films where it was a small group of people on an isolated island. Even if you havent seen the previous films I would highly recommend seeing thisHelpful?Yes|NoReplyShareMoreShow More Share Tweet 0 Shares Top About us Work for Time Out Privacy policy Website terms of use Contact us Get listed Advertising Time Out products Mobile apps Time Out Shop Time Out Guides Time Out Travel Time Out Worldwide Time Out magazine Follow us Facebook Twitter Youtube Instagram Pinterest Spotify Foursquare Time Out New York Site map }

Review Jurassic World a pulse-pounding triumph - Mercury News Hot Topics Bay Area festivals Adele Double Exposure Pokemon Go tips Hollywood Vampires Lesher Jazz series Billy Hart Odysseo Hurt Village Print Email Font ResizeReview Jurassic World a pulse-pounding triumphBy Tony Hicksthicksbayareanewsgroup.comPosted 06/10/2015 112558 AM PDTUpdated 06/10/2015 053624 PM PDT Related StoriesJun 10Jurassic World 5 best dinosaurs in pop cultureJun 10Jurassic World 5 best dinosaurs in pop cultureDuring the first half-hour of "Jurassic World" the idea of cooking up a new dinosaur species in a lab seems more believable than some of the human dialogue in the film.Thank goodness for giant dinosaurs who enjoy devouring tourists so we dont have to pay too much attention to what else is going on.Actually "Jurassic World" gets better as it goes along. And while it might not top the groundbreaking 1993 "Jurassic Park" it definitely is the best of the three sequels. Of course it follows the familiar drill Humans mess with nature despite the obvious risks; nature strikes back; humans run for their lives and not all of them make it. The Indominus Rex readies her attack in Jurassic World. (Universal Pictures) ( Universal Pictures ) But some things are different this time. For one thing we get more empathetic and likable characters (cmon admit it you kind of wanted to see those kids in "Jurassic Park" end up on the T-rexs plate). We also get great pacing compared to the first three films which frequently were bogged down and took too much time setting up the big moments. Once "Jurassic World" gets moving it explodes into a big roller coaster ride that lasts just long enough and never spends too much time in one place. And despite the silly dialogue and some wince-inducing character stereotypes early on "Jurassic World" is a well-constructed film with a clear convincing plot progression and a surprisingly good ending.Advertisement Its been a couple of decades since John Hammond hatched -- literally -- his dream of turning an island full of cloned dinosaurs into a theme park. Now with Claire Dearing (Bryce Dallas Howard) at the helm Jurassic World runs like a well-oiled clock with 20000 tourists streaming into a setup that looks like Disneyland Tahiti. As long as the suits can reinvigorate the park with a new feature every few years all is well with the investors. Then scientists go too far and design something called an Indominous rex. Chris Pratt as Owen Grady in Jurassic World. (Universal Pictures) ( Universal Pictures ) Unfortunately -- at least for the trainers a SWAT team some military contractors and a bunch of peaceful plant-eating dinos -- the resulting new dinosaur is the equivalent of a terribly intelligent serial killer the size of a five-story building.Chris Pratt plays Owen Grady a former Navy specialist who works as the trainer and alpha male of the parks pack of velociraptors. His relationship with Claire is that of a spurned almost-boyfriend which at first results in some flat and tedious attempts at humor. Hes also the voice of reason when contractor Vic Hoskins (Vincent DOnofrio in an over-the-top role that isnt clearly explained) schemes to turn the velociraptors into military weapons to use against enemies in the Middle East.Also thrown into the mix are Claires two nephews visiting the park for the first time. They function more or less as the barometer for Claires transition from icy business woman to loving aunt. And of course they fill the films need for children who are constantly in danger of becoming human pizza rolls.Even with its flaws "Jurassic World" works thanks to director Colin Trevorrows great sense of pacing and flair for drama that transcends the idea of beasts chasing humans. Theres a terror-inducing escape of rampaging pterodactyls that looks like a modern-day scene from "The Birds" and great tension generated in another scene in which the velociraptors have to decide where their allegiance lies. It would be perfectly fair to expect more of the same from a fourth movie about escaped dinosaurs chasing people but "Jurassic World" shows a real evolution in quality with its blend of gorgeous photography special effects storytelling and characters who round out and become affecting by the films end. Plus removing Sam Neill and his characters wet towel personality was addition by subtraction. All these qualities make "Jurassic World" a great candidate for popcorn movie of the summer. Especially for a new generation of moviegoers who havent experienced the thrill of dinosaurs seemingly jumping off the big screen to eat them.
